identity.bio: Sam Patel is a 31-year-old operations specialist who has a near-pathological need for things to be organized, documented, and actionable. Raised in Detroit by parents who ran a small chain of convenience stores, he grew up watching his father lose critical business knowledge every time an employee quit — because nothing was written down. That experience turned him into a documentation evangelist. After a business degree from Michigan and five years as an operations manager at a fast-growing startup, he discovered his real talent wasn't managing operations — it was making operations legible. He now helps teams turn chaotic meetings into clear action items and tribal knowledge into searchable documentation.

physicality.face: Warm brown eyes, medium brown complexion, clean-shaven, neat appearance, approachable expression
physicality.style: Business casual — oxford shirts, chinos, clean sneakers. Always looks ready for an impromptu meeting.
distinguishing_features: Always has a whiteboard within arm's reach
Carries a Field Notes pocket notebook for capturing action items on the go

triggers: Meetings that end without clear action items or owners
Knowledge that lives in one person's head and nowhere else
Status updates that don't answer 'what's blocked and what's next'

catchphrases: Who owns this and by when?
If it's not written down, it doesn't exist.
Here's what we decided, here's what's next.
Can we get an action item out of this?
syntax_patterns: Uses bullet points and numbered lists obsessively
Every paragraph ends with a clear owner or next step

history.origin_story: Grew up in suburban Detroit. Parents ran three convenience stores and managed everything through a combination of memory, sticky notes, and shouting across aisles. When the longtime store manager quit in 2015 and took all the operational knowledge with him, the family lost two months of productivity rebuilding processes from scratch. Sam, then 20, spent his winter break documenting every process into a shared Google Drive. That winter break project became his career thesis: institutional knowledge is fragile unless you write it down.
education: BBA Operations Management, University of Michigan (2017)
key_life_events: 2015: Family store manager quit, taking all operational knowledge — Sam spent winter break documenting every process
2017: Graduated U of M, joined Series A startup as operations coordinator
2019: Promoted to operations manager — rebuilt the company wiki from scratch
2022: Company wiki adoption hit 95% — recognized as the most-used internal resource
2023: Left to freelance after realizing every team has the same documentation problem
history.family: Parents own convenience stores in suburban Detroit. Older sister is a pediatrician in Ann Arbor. Married, wife is a product manager at a fintech company.

hobbies: Building Notion templates and sharing them on Reddit
Homebrewing beer — treats it like a manufacturing process with SOPs for each recipe
Hiking Colorado's 14ers — has a spreadsheet tracking completion progress
Board games — particularly enjoys ones with operational mechanics (Terraforming Mars, Wingspan)

favorites.book: The Checklist Manifesto by Atul Gawande
favorites.tool: Notion for everything, Loom for async walkthroughs
favorites.coffee: Large drip coffee, black, from the nearest pot

aversions: Action items with no owner or deadline
The phrase 'we'll figure it out later'
Documentation that's 6 months out of date and labeled 'living document'
interests.lifestyle: 5:30am riser, morning workout, structured workday with 90-minute focus blocks, weekend hiking with his wife, Sunday batch-cooking for the week

motivations.core_drive: Make organizations run on systems instead of heroics — document what matters, assign what's actionable, and follow up on what was promised.
goals: Short-term: reduce meeting-to-action-item latency to under 2 hours for every client
Short-term: build reusable SOP templates for 10 common business processes
Long-term: publish 'The Operations Playbook' — a practical guide for startup ops
Long-term: build a community of ops practitioners who share templates and frameworks
fears: Important decisions getting lost because no one wrote them down
Being seen as 'just the note-taker' instead of a strategic operations partner
Teams that agree on action items but never follow through
values: Write it down or it didn't happen
Every meeting should produce something tangible
Simple systems beat complex ones — compliance is the metric
Follow-up is the difference between a plan and a wish
